comment_text.mn80:2.1: Vekhanasa, the “descendant of Vikhānasa” was, according to the commentary, the teacher of Sakaludāyī and came to defend his teaching. The Vekhanasas were Vedic poets. They became known in later Sanskrit texts as an order of forest-dwelling ascetics, who evolved into the modern Vaikhānasa Vishnavite tradition. This sutta may be the earliest reference to a tradition of Vekhanasa ascetics, creating a link between the Vedic poets and the later tradition. The Buddha calls him by his personal or clan name Kaccāna.
comment_text.mn80:2.4: The Rig Veda features two Vaikhānasa poems, one of which describes Soma as “most resplendent” (śubhraśastamaḥ, Rig Veda 9.66.26), a phrase notably parallel in meaning to the Pali “ultimate splendor” (paramo vaṇṇo). These verses are rich with similar imagery: Soma is a “gleaming light” (24) whose “glittering drops” “flash with radiance” (25), “pervading with rays” (27), a “heaven-bright milk” (30). This poem is ascribed to “a hundred Vaikhānasas”, suggesting that an order already existed at the time. Perhaps the Vekhanasa lineage developed their philosophy from these verses, which they had recited over so many centuries that the original referent, Soma, was forgotten.
comment_text.mn80:13.2: The introductory iti (“so they say”) indicates that the Buddha is quoting a saying, which may not have originated with him. | The “pleasure that surmounts the sensual” (kāmaggasukha) is defined by the commentary as Nibbāna, which explains why the Buddha says below that only arahants can truly understand this saying (MN 80:14.8). | Compare with the passage on extracting cream of ghee, which uses parallel syntax (DN 9:52.1, SN 34.1:1.9, AN 4.95:4.1).

root_text.mn80:2.1: Atha kho vekhanaso paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.mn80:2.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn80:2.3: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho vekhanaso paribbājako bhagavato santike udānaṁ udānesi:
root_text.mn80:2.8: “Yasmā, bho gotama, vaṇṇā añño vaṇṇo uttaritaro vā paṇītataro vā natthi so paramo vaṇṇo”ti.

root_text.mn80:4.1: “Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato paṇḍukambale nikkhitto bhāsate ca tapate ca virocati ca, evaṁ vaṇṇo attā hoti arogo paraṁ maraṇā”ti.

root_text.mn80:11.1: “Ato kho te, kaccāna, bahū hi bahutarā devā ye imesaṁ candimasūriyānaṁ ābhā nānubhonti, tyāhaṁ pajānāmi.

root_text.mn80:11.4: Atha ca pana tvaṁ, kaccāna, ‘yvāyaṁ vaṇṇo kiminā khajjopanakena nihīnataro ca patikiṭṭhataro ca so paramo vaṇṇo’ti vadesi; tañca vaṇṇaṁ na paññapesi.
root_text.mn80:12.3: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,

root_text.mn80:13.1: Yaṁ kho, kaccāna, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ idaṁ vuccati kāmasukhaṁ.
root_text.mn80:13.2: Iti kāmehi kāmasukhaṁ, kāmasukhā kāmaggasukhaṁ tattha aggamakkhāyatī”ti.
root_text.mn80:14.1: Evaṁ vutte, vekhanaso paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn80:14.5: ‘Kāmehi, bho gotama, kāmasukhaṁ, kāmasukhā kāmaggasukhaṁ, tattha aggamakkhāyatī’”ti
root_text.mn80:14.6: “dujjānaṁ kho etaṁ, kaccāna, tayā aññadiṭṭhikena aññakhantikena aññarucikena aññatrayogena aññatrācariyakena—
root_text.mn80:14.7: kāmā vā kāmasukhaṁ vā kāmaggasukhaṁ vā.
root_text.mn80:14.8: Ye kho te, kaccāna, bhikkhū arahanto khīṇāsavā vusitavanto katakaraṇīyā ohitabhārā anuppattasadatthā parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojanā sammadaññāvimuttā te kho etaṁ jāneyyuṁ—

root_text.mn80:15.1: Evaṁ vutte, vekhanaso paribbājako kupito anattamano bhagavantaṁyeva khuṁsento bhagavantaṁyeva vambhento bhagavantaṁyeva vadamāno:
root_text.mn80:15.3: “evameva panidhekacce samaṇabrāhmaṇā ajānantā pubbantaṁ, apassantā aparantaṁ atha ca pana
root_text.mn80:15.4: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti—pajānāmā’ti—paṭijānanti.
root_text.mn80:15.5: Tesamidaṁ bhāsitaṁ hassakaṁyeva sampajjati, nāmakaṁyeva sampajjati, rittakaṁyeva sampajjati, tucchakaṁyeva sampajjatī”ti.

root_text.mn80:16.2: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyāti—pajānāmā’ti—paṭijānanti;
root_text.mn80:16.4: Api ca, kaccāna, tiṭṭhatu pubbanto, tiṭṭhatu aparanto.
root_text.mn80:16.5: Etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi.
root_text.mn80:16.6: Yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno nacirasseva sāmaññeva ñassati sāmaṁ dakkhiti—
root_text.mn80:16.7: evaṁ kira sammā bandhanā vippamokkho hoti, yadidaṁ avijjā bandhanā.
root_text.mn80:16.8: Seyyathāpi, kaccāna, daharo kumāro mando uttānaseyyako kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi baddho assa suttabandhanehi;
root_text.mn80:16.9: tassa vuddhimanvāya indriyānaṁ paripākamanvāya tāni bandhanāni mucceyyuṁ;
root_text.mn80:16.10: so mokkhomhīti kho jāneyya no ca bandhanaṁ.
root_text.mn80:16.11: Evameva kho, kaccāna, etu viññū puriso asaṭho amāyāvī ujujātiko, ahamanusāsāmi, ahaṁ dhammaṁ desemi;
root_text.mn80:16.12: yathānusiṭṭhaṁ tathā paṭipajjamāno nacirasseva sāmaññeva ñassati, sāmaṁ dakkhiti:
root_text.mn80:16.13: ‘evaṁ kira sammā bandhanā vippamokkho hoti, yadidaṁ avijjā bandhanā’”ti.
root_text.mn80:17.1: Evaṁ vutte, vekhanaso paribbājako bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn80:17.3: upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.

translation_text.mn80:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn80:2.1: Then the wanderer Vekhanasa went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.mn80:2.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side,
translation_text.mn80:2.4: “This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.”
translation_text.mn80:2.6: ‘This is the ultimate splendor, this is the ultimate splendor.’
translation_text.mn80:2.8: “Worthy Gotama, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”
translation_text.mn80:2.9: “But what is that ultimate splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer?”
translation_text.mn80:2.10: “Worthy Gotama, the ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.”
translation_text.mn80:3.1: “Kaccāna, you could draw this out for a long time.
translation_text.mn80:3.2: You say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.
translation_text.mn80:3.3: Suppose a man was to say,
translation_text.mn80:3.4: ‘Whoever the finest lady in the land is, it is her that I want, her I desire!’
translation_text.mn80:3.6: ‘Worthy man, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know whether she’s an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial?’
translation_text.mn80:3.9: ‘Mister, that finest lady in the land who you desire—do you know her name or clan? Whether she’s tall or short or medium? Whether her skin is black, brown, or dingy? What village, town, or city she comes from?’
translation_text.mn80:3.12: ‘Worthy man, do you desire someone who you’ve never even known or seen?’
translation_text.mn80:3.15: This being so, doesn’t that man’s statement turn out to have no demonstrable basis?”
translation_text.mn80:3.17: “In the same way, you say, ‘The ultimate splendor is the splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’ But you don’t describe that splendor.”
translation_text.mn80:4.1: “Mister Gotama, suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally lustrous, eight-faceted, well-worked. When placed on a cream rug it would shine and glow and radiate. Such is the splendor of the self that is free of disease after death.”
translation_text.mn80:5.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: such a beryl gem, or a firefly in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn80:5.3: “A firefly in the dark of night.”
translation_text.mn80:6.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: a firefly in the dark of night, or an oil lamp in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn80:6.3: “An oil lamp in the dark of night.”
translation_text.mn80:7.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: an oil lamp in the dark of night, or a great mass of fire in the dark of night?”
translation_text.mn80:7.3: “A great mass of fire in the dark of night.”
translation_text.mn80:8.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: a great mass of fire in the dark of night, or the Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn?”
translation_text.mn80:8.3: “The Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn.”
translation_text.mn80:9.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: the Morning Star in the clear and cloudless heavens at the crack of dawn, or the full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath?”
translation_text.mn80:9.3: “The full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath.”
translation_text.mn80:10.2: Which of these two has a finer splendor: the full moon at midnight in the clear and cloudless heavens on the fifteenth day sabbath, or the sun at midday in the clear and cloudless heavens in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn?”
translation_text.mn80:10.3: “The sun at midday in the clear and cloudless heavens in the last month of the rainy season, in autumn.”
translation_text.mn80:11.1: “Beyond this, Kaccāna, I know very many gods on whom the luminosity of the sun and moon makes no impression.
translation_text.mn80:11.3: ‘The splendor compared to which no other splendor is finer.’
translation_text.mn80:11.4: But of the splendor inferior to a firefly you say, ‘This is the ultimate splendor.’ And you don’t describe that splendor.
translation_text.mn80:12.1: Kaccāna, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn80:12.3: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn80:12.7: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn80:12.8: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn80:13.1: The pleasure and happiness that arises from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure.
translation_text.mn80:13.2: ‘From the senses comes sensual pleasure. Beyond sensual pleasure is the pleasure that surmounts the sensual, which is said to be the best of these.’”
translation_text.mn80:14.1: When he said this, Vekhanasa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn80:14.3: How well said this was by the worthy Gotama!
translation_text.mn80:14.4: ‘From the senses comes sensual pleasure. Beyond sensual pleasure is the pleasure that surmounts the sensual, which is said to be the best of these.’
translation_text.mn80:14.5: Worthy Gotama, from the senses comes sensual pleasure. Beyond sensual pleasure is the pleasure that surmounts the sensual, which is said to be the best of these.”
translation_text.mn80:14.6: “Kaccāna, since you have a different view, creed, and belief, then, unless you dedicate yourself to practice with the guidance of tradition, it’s hard for you to understand
translation_text.mn80:14.7: the senses, sensual pleasure, and the pleasure that surmounts the sensual.
translation_text.mn80:14.8: There are mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. They can understand
translation_text.mn80:14.9: the senses, sensual pleasure, and the pleasure that surmounts the sensual.”
translation_text.mn80:15.1: When he said this, Vekhanasa became angry and upset. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying,
translation_text.mn80:15.2: “The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn80:15.3: “This is exactly what happens with some ascetics and brahmins. Not knowing the first beginning or seeing the final end, they nevertheless claim:
translation_text.mn80:15.4: ‘We understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’
translation_text.mn80:15.5: Their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, vacuous and hollow.”
translation_text.mn80:16.1: “Kaccāna, there are some ascetics and brahmins who, not knowing the first beginning or seeing the final end, nevertheless claim:
translation_text.mn80:16.2: ‘We understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.”’
translation_text.mn80:16.3: There is a legitimate refutation of them.
translation_text.mn80:16.4: Nevertheless, Kaccāna, leave aside the first beginning and the final end.
translation_text.mn80:16.5: Let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
translation_text.mn80:16.6: Practicing as instructed they will soon know and see for themselves,
translation_text.mn80:16.7: ‘So this is how to be rightly released from the bond, that is, the bond of ignorance.’
translation_text.mn80:16.8: Suppose there was a little baby bound with swaddling up to the neck.
translation_text.mn80:16.9: As they grow up and their senses mature, they’re accordingly released from those bonds.
translation_text.mn80:16.10: They’d know ‘I’m released,’ and there would be no more bonds.
translation_text.mn80:16.11: In the same way, let a sensible person come—neither devious nor deceitful, a person of integrity. I teach and instruct them.
translation_text.mn80:16.12: Practicing as instructed they will soon know and see for themselves,
translation_text.mn80:16.13: ‘So this is how to be rightly released from the bond, that is, the bond of ignorance.’”
translation_text.mn80:17.1: When he said this, Vekhanasa said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn80:17.3: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
